    joshnuss
    Jan 15, 2021

    -

    Update: we plan to support transactions. Follow issue PostgREST/postgrest#286 for the latest.

    It would be handy if there was a way to execute multiple operations within a transaction. Similar to Ecto.Multi.

    Maybe something like:

    await supabase.transaction(
  supabase.from(...).insert(...),
  supabase.from(...).update(...)
)

    Would reduce the number of situations where a postgres function is needed.

    miketromba
    Dec 21, 2021

    -

    I find firebase's transactions and batched writes APIs to be very useful and developer-friendly. It would be fantastic to see something similar integrated into supabase. As it stands, this is a huge sticking-point for me when deciding to use supabase vs alternatives. Learning and writing RPCs each time we want to do a simple batched write / atomic transaction is not fun.

    Firebase docs on transactions / batched writes: https://firebase.google.com/docs/firestore/manage-data/transactions#batched-writes

    Example of firebase batching API from their docs:

    import { writeBatch, doc } from "firebase/firestore"; 

// Get a new write batch
const batch = writeBatch(db);

// Set the value of 'NYC'
const nycRef = doc(db, "cities", "NYC");
batch.set(nycRef, {name: "New York City"});

// Update the population of 'SF'
const sfRef = doc(db, "cities", "SF");
batch.update(sfRef, {"population": 1000000});

// Delete the city 'LA'
const laRef = doc(db, "cities", "LA");
batch.delete(laRef);

// Commit the batch
await batch.commit();

    Original comment on other thread: https://github.com/supabase/supabase-js/issues/87#issuecomment-999147766

    lab-bone-Max
    Mar 8, 2022

    -

    Supabase-cli is a step in the right direction in a CI/CD workflow but to suggest using RPC functions to get transactions is shamelessly trite.
    I love Supabase and see potential but to evolve beyond 'demo' ToDo and chat applications then RPC is not workable. No project is going to be written in SQL and we tried PLV8 but that is just another layer of problems that are not integrated with version control, symbols, debugging etc.
    We are building an ERM and have sufficient pre-flighting and low concurrency to live without transactions. I don't like it but can live with it however for the platform to evolve then needs to change.
    It's not like transactions need to be built from the ground up as Postgres has done the herculean groundwork. I'm not trivialising the work as I know PostgREST does not have transactions but that's because it is stateless.
    The supabase client runs local so state/session management during the transaction is far from impossible and easily enforceable as a predicate.

    steve-chavez Mar 16, 2022

    -

    Just to point out that we got all of this feedback guys. Long-running transactions is definitely on the roadmap: supabase/postgrest-js#219

    Agreed. I've integrated Prisma client into my app for transactions and atomic operations...

    Do note that it's not an apples to apples comparison, Prisma is a backend library AFAIK and you cannot use it as a frontend library. The point of PostgREST and the supabase client libraries is to access a safe subset of SQL directly in your web applications.

    illia-romanenko
    Sep 7, 2023

    -

    Wanted to share a relatively new option to transactions in Supabase, and while this is not an ideal alternative to client transactions, it could be better in some ways than writing stored procedures: with release of Supabase Edge Functions - there is a way to connect to Postgres directly: https://supabase.com/docs/guides/functions/connect-to-postgres thus have access to transactions API.

    So instead of writing PL/pgSQL you can write JS/TS (or even Dart) and potentially reuse some of your code.

    barbinbrad Jul 22, 2024

    -

    I think there's a good reason. It's because PostgREST doesn't implement transactions. See locked discussion: PostgREST/postgrest#286

    But just personally, I don't love the response of "just use a function". Of course, it's no problem when you have low amounts of business logic. But when you have to implement a lot of custom logic, it's just untenable to do it all in SQL.

    For example, if someone was willing to show me how easy it is to implement something like this in a SQL function, I would be happy to move in that direction:

    https://gist.github.com/barbinbrad/5bf2d79b2ff75fd185009be40fb7d4fe#file-index-ts-L955

    While SQL is definitely a turning-complete language -- there's a reason no one (guessing) uses it to do Advent of Code

    barbinbrad Jul 22, 2024

    -

    Here's claude's implementation (pretty impressive tbh). Not sure if it works, but it seems like there's enough there to get me going:

    CREATE OR REPLACE FUNCTION process_purchase_invoice(
    p_invoice_id UUID,
    p_company_id UUID,
    p_created_by UUID,
    p_receipt_line_inserts JSONB,
    p_purchase_order_line_updates JSONB,
    p_journal_line_inserts JSONB,
    p_item_ledger_inserts JSONB,
    p_cost_ledger_inserts JSONB
) RETURNS VOID AS $$
DECLARE
    v_today DATE := CURRENT_DATE;
    v_accounting_period_id UUID;
    v_journal_id UUID;
    v_receipt_id UUID;
    v_readable_receipt_id TEXT;
BEGIN
    -- Start transaction
    BEGIN
        -- Get accounting period ID (you'll need to implement this function)
        SELECT get_accounting_period_id(v_today, p_company_id) INTO v_accounting_period_id;

        -- Process receipt lines
        IF jsonb_array_length(p_receipt_line_inserts) > 0 THEN
            FOR location_data IN SELECT * FROM jsonb_each(p_receipt_line_inserts)
            LOOP
                -- Generate readable receipt ID (you'll need to implement this function)
                SELECT get_next_sequence('receipt', p_company_id) INTO v_readable_receipt_id;

                -- Insert receipt
                INSERT INTO receipt (
                    "receiptId", "locationId", "sourceDocument", "sourceDocumentId",
                    "sourceDocumentReadableId", "externalDocumentId", "supplierId",
                    status, "postingDate", invoiced, "companyId", "createdBy"
                )
                SELECT 
                    v_readable_receipt_id,
                    (location_data.value->0->>'locationId')::UUID,
                    'Purchase Invoice',
                    p_invoice_id,
                    -- You'll need to get these values from somewhere
                    (SELECT "invoiceId" FROM purchase_invoice WHERE id = p_invoice_id),
                    (SELECT "supplierReference" FROM purchase_invoice WHERE id = p_invoice_id),
                    (SELECT "supplierId" FROM purchase_invoice WHERE id = p_invoice_id),
                    'Posted',
                    v_today,
                    TRUE,
                    p_company_id,
                    p_created_by
                RETURNING id INTO v_receipt_id;

                -- Insert receipt lines
                INSERT INTO receipt_line (
                    -- Add all necessary fields here
                    "receiptId"
                )
                SELECT 
                    -- Add all necessary fields here
                    v_receipt_id
                FROM jsonb_to_recordset(location_data.value) AS x(
                    -- Define the structure of your receipt line data here
                );
            END LOOP;
        END IF;

        -- Update purchase order lines
        FOR po_line IN SELECT * FROM jsonb_each(p_purchase_order_line_updates)
        LOOP
            UPDATE purchase_order_line
            SET -- Set the fields based on po_line.value
            WHERE id = (po_line.key)::UUID;
        END LOOP;

        -- Update purchase orders
        -- This part is complex and would require multiple nested loops and queries
        -- You may want to create a separate function for this logic

        -- Insert journal
        INSERT INTO journal (
            "accountingPeriodId", description, "postingDate", "companyId"
        ) VALUES (
            v_accounting_period_id,
            'Purchase Invoice ' || (SELECT "invoiceId" FROM purchase_invoice WHERE id = p_invoice_id),
            v_today,
            p_company_id
        ) RETURNING id INTO v_journal_id;

        -- Insert journal lines
        INSERT INTO journal_line (
            -- Add all necessary fields here
            "journalId"
        )
        SELECT 
            -- Add all necessary fields here
            v_journal_id
        FROM jsonb_to_recordset(p_journal_line_inserts) AS x(
            -- Define the structure of your journal line data here
        );

        -- Insert item ledger entries
        IF jsonb_array_length(p_item_ledger_inserts) > 0 THEN
            INSERT INTO item_ledger (
                -- Add all necessary fields here
            )
            SELECT * FROM jsonb_to_recordset(p_item_ledger_inserts) AS x(
                -- Define the structure of your item ledger data here
            );
        END IF;

        -- Insert cost ledger entries
        IF jsonb_array_length(p_cost_ledger_inserts) > 0 THEN
            INSERT INTO cost_ledger (
                -- Add all necessary fields here
            )
            SELECT * FROM jsonb_to_recordset(p_cost_ledger_inserts) AS x(
                -- Define the structure of your cost ledger data here
            );
        END IF;

        -- Update purchase invoice
        UPDATE purchase_invoice
        SET
            "postingDate" = v_today,
            status = 'Submitted'
        WHERE id = p_invoice_id;

    -- End transaction
    EXCEPTION WHEN OTHERS THEN
        RAISE;
    END;
END;
$$ LANGUAGE plpgsql;

    willdavidow
    Sep 21, 2024

    -

    It seems like this thread has devolved into a bunch of complaints around lack of support for transactions.

    The folks at Supabase are surely aware that this is a very desired feature and have provided the bandaid of support via functions (yes I'm aware this is hard to maintain and less than ideal), but: complaining and one word comments, gifs, and so on are just useless noise.

    I'm sure the feature is on their roadmap, or maybe there are technical roadblocks that would require too much work? I don't know, but this IS an open source platform. It seems like one path to figuring out how/if transactions can be added would be looking at what's missing from PostgREST, adding the functionality there and then integrating it into the various client libs.

    I'm not saying that's easy, or even possible, but instead of complaints and gifs, maybe we could all figure out ways to contribute to the project/community and work together to try and make this feature happen.

    thibault-chausson
    Oct 31, 2024

    -

    Supabase response

    
Hi Thibault,

I think what you would like to know is when the library will support arbitrary queries. You can write any query within a database function and then call it from the front-end as an RPC. However, this does require some context switching: going from writing SQL to JS depending on the need.

In general, there aren't any imminent plans to implement this feature outside of RPCs. The PostgREST community has been going back and fourth on this for quite some time. It may be better to bring this up in PostgREST's GitHub to see if they can provide a more concrete answer.

Still, it's important for our teams to be aware of the demand for certain features. I'll share this with the PostgREST team to keep them informed.

Best,
Brian Brennglass
Supabase Support Engineer

    joshdance
    Jan 4, 2025

    Original comment in English -

    Welcome to the new year 2025! If anyone finds this looking for transaction support here is the latest info I could gather.

    Currently not supported. Currently not on the roadmap. There are several workarounds.

    You can encapsulate the logic in a Postgres SQL function then call it with rpc
    You can do use supabase Edge functions to run a bunch of changes as a transaction - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xUeuy19a-Uw
    You can use an ORM like Prisma - https://www.prisma.io/docs/orm/prisma-client/queries/transactions

    This issue is 4 years old. So make your comment asking for it, vote up the other posts you find useful or want to support etc.

    Did I miss anything?
